questions.text: The following statements are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: The inflammatory phase of wound healing lasts for 5 to 7 days

options.label: B
options.text: Platelet-rich blood clots and dilated vessels are typical of the inflammatory phase

options.label: C
options.text: Fibroblastic activity is the main feature of the proliferative phase

options.label: D
options.text: In a tendon injury, fibrous adhesion between the tendon and its sheath is an important mechanism of healing

questions.correct_answer: A. The inflammatory phase of wound healing lasts for 5 to 7 days
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The inflammatory phase of wound healing lasts for 5 to 7 days The inflammatory phase of wound healing lasts for 2 to 3 days. Normal wound healing occurs in three phases – the inflammatory phase lasts for the first 2 to 3 days, the proliferative phase lasts for 3 days to 3 weeks and, finally, the remodeling (maturation) phase lasts from the end of the third week to years.

Highyeild:

Wound Healing: Inflammation : In the early inflammatory phase (days 1–2) , platelet activation causes an infux of inflammatory cells led by polymorphonuclear leukocytes, particularly neutrophils . During the late inflammatory phase (days 2–3) monocytes appear in the wound and differentiate into macrophages

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. The inflammatory phase, also called the exudative phase has no tensile strength to the wound . It consists of vascular, cellular, and enzymatic processes. As a result of the wound, bleeding, vasoconstriction, and thrombus formation occurs. Platelets stick to the damaged vessel endothelium, releasing adenosine diphosphate (ADP), cytokines, serotonin, prostaglandins, and histamine. This causes vascular permeability, resulting in the migration of inflammatory cells and macrophages, the latter removing devitalized tissue and microorganisms. Fibrinogen produces fibrin, which forms the framework for fibroblastic activity, which is the second phase . Option C . The proliferative phase lasts from 3 days to the end of the third week. The principal feature of this is a fibroblastic activity with the production of collagen and new capillaries (angiogenesis) and re-epithelialization; this is called granulation tissue . This increased collagen gives the wound almost one-third of its original tensile strength . The third phase of remodeling constitutes re-arrangement and cross-linking of collagen fibers , which can go on for years while the wound regains 80% of its original tensile strength. Option D. Wound healing in special situations such as tendon consists of intrinsic and extrinsic mechanisms, the latter depending upon fibrous adhesions between the tendon and its sheath

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true? a. The aim of the treatment of a wound is to reduce the inflammatory and proliferative responses. b. The mechanism of wounding influences the healing of a wound. c. There is no role for tests for hepatitis and HIV when managing wounds. d. Primary repair of all damaged structures should be attempted in all wounds. e. Healing by tertiary intention should be the choice in certain situations. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a, b, and e The aim should always be to achieve healing by primary intention. (Statement a) This can occur by reducing the inflammatory and proliferative responses. By doing so, healing occurs by first or primary intention when the wound edges are accurately opposed, leaving minimal scarring. ( Statement b) The mechanism of a wound has a profound bearing on the healing. For example, a clean-cut incision in an elective operation will heal well with the least prominent scar. On the other hand, a crush injury or one following burn will take a long time to heal and do so by secondary intention with ugly scarring. ( Statement e) In certain situations, such as emergency abdominal surgery in fecal peritonitis where the wound would be inevitably contaminated, it is prudent to leave the abdominal wall open after closing the peritoneum. Delayed closure of the wound is carried out when the inflammatory and proliferative phases of wound healing are well established. This is referred to as closure by tertiary or delayed primary intention.

Highyeild:

Wound Healing: Stages Haemostasis Disruption of the vascular endothelium following injury causes vasoconstriction and exposure of the subendothelial extracellular matrix. This encourages platelets to adhere, activate and aggregate, resulting in a platelet plug, which also helps limit further blood loss. (A)Inflammation : In the early inflammatory phase (days 1–2) , platelet activation causes an influx of inflammatory cells led by polymorphonuclear leukocytes, particularly neutrophils . During the late inflammatory phase (days 2–3) monocytes appear in the wound and differentiate into macrophages (B)Proliferation : The proliferative phase starts around day 3 and lasts for 2–4 weeks . It consists mainly of fibroblast activity with the production of ground substance (glycosaminoglycans and proteoglycans), collagen, angiogenesis, and re-epithelialization of the wound . The wound tissue formed in the early part of this phase is called granulation tissue . In the later part of this phase, there is an increase in the tensile strength of the wound as a result of increased collagen synthesized by fibroblasts . These play an important role in contraction to bring the edges of the wound together (C) Remodelling : Begins 2–3 weeks after injury and lasts for a year or more . This phase is characterized by maturation of collagen . Type III collagen, which is prevalent during proliferation, is replaced by stronger type I collagen until the normal skin ratio of 4:1 type I to type III collagen is re-established

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Statement C. is incorrect because: There is a role for testing hepatitis and HIV viruses when multiple victims from the same site (terrorist-related injuries or bus crashes) have been brought in because these will carry the risk of tissue and viral contamination. Statement D. is incorrect because: Primary repair of structures such as bone, tendon, soft tissue, nerve and vessels should not be attempted in all wounds. Such repair should be carried out only in a tidy wound. Staged procedures should be attempted in untidy wounds such as explosions.

questions.text: Which one of the following statements is false?

options.label: A
options.text: In case of severe uncontrollable bleeding, a soft clamp must be applied immediately across the vessel in the wound

options.label: B
options.text: Wounds should be classified as tidy and untidy before deciding upon intervention

options.label: C
options.text: Repair of all damaged structures can be attempted under certain situations

options.label: D
options.text: Pulsed jet lavage for saline irrigation is not always ideal for saline irrigation

questions.correct_answer: A. In case of severe uncontrollable bleeding, a soft clamp must be applied immediately across the vessel in the wound
questions.explanation:
Solution:

In case of severe uncontrollable bleeding, a soft clamp must be applied immediately across the vessel in the wound In severe uncontrollable bleeding, a clamp should never be applied because nerves may be irreparably damaged . The bleeding wound should be elevated and a pressure pad applied until the wound can be properly examined under adequate analgesia or anesthesia (local, regional, or general). When appropriate, this examination is carried out under the use of a tourniquet .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. Wounds are classified as ‘tidy’ and ‘untidy’ to help in their management. Tidy wounds are those with a clean incision on healthy tissue without any tissue loss. Untidy wounds are caused by crush or avulsion injuries and are contaminated where there is tissue loss with ischemia . Option C. Repair of all damaged structures may be attempted in a tidy wound . Vessels, nerves, and tendons are repaired, magnification is used whenever necessary. Option D. Wound irrigation with large amounts of saline is carried out as a part of debridement. Irrigation by pulsed jet lavage is not always advisable , because the procedure can push the dirt further deep into tissue planes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about skin incisions?

options.label: A
options.text: Skin incisions are best made along tension lines

options.label: B
options.text: Incisions should avoid bony prominences and skin creases

options.label: C
options.text: The 22-blade scalpel is ideal for all incisions

options.label: D
options.text: Incisions should be made bearing in mind cosmesis

questions.correct_answer: C. The 22-blade scalpel is ideal for all incisions
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The 22-blade scalpel is ideal for all incisions The 22-blade scalpel is not ideal for all incisions. It is best reserved for making an abdominal incision; the 15-blade is for minor procedures and the 11-blade is for arteriotomy.

Highyeild:

Skin Incisions: Skin incisions are made using a scalpel with the blade pressed firmly down at right angles to the skin and then drawn gently across the skin in the desired direction to create a clean incision Scalpel Blades : 22-blade - Abdominal incisions 11-blade - Arteriotomy and abscess drainage and 15-blade - Minor surgical procedures

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Skin incisions are best made along Langers’ lines (tension lines), which represent the direction of dermal collagen fibers. Therefore, incisions made parallel to these lines result in a good scar, the surgeon’s signature, which is the only part of the operation the patient actually sees. Option B, D. They should avoid bony prominences and skin creases and should take into account the final cosmetic result. The latter factor should not however be of paramount importance, as any incision should provide adequate access to make the operation safe and functionally effective. Transverse abdominal incisions cut through fewer dermatomes and hence produce less postoperative pain. Therefore, the patient coughs much better producing less respiratory complications.

questions.text: The following statements are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: Mass closure technique is the usual method used for abdominal wall

options.label: B
options.text: Sutures lose 50% of their tensile strength at the knot

options.label: C
options.text: Non-absorbable suture material should be used in the biliary and urinary tract

options.label: D
options.text: Synthetic suture materials elicit minimal tissue reaction

questions.correct_answer: C. Non-absorbable suture material should be used in the biliary and urinary tract
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Non-absorbable suture material should be used in the biliary and urinary tract Non-absorbable suture material should not be used in the biliary tract and urinary tract, as they would act as a nidus for a stone. Absorbable sutures should always be used when closing the common bile duct or placing sutures anywhere from the renal pelvis down to the urinary bladder.

Highyeild:

Suturing Technique: The suturing of an incision or wound needs to take into consideration the site and tissues involved. There is no ideal wound closure technique that would be appropriate for all situations. Suture material: Desired characteristics Suture material: desired characteristics Easy to handle Predictable behaviour in tissues Predictable tensile strength Sterile Glides through tissues easily Secure knotting ability Inexpensive Minimal tissue reaction Non-capillary Non-allergenic Non-carcinogenic The basic five characteristics of a suture material to be considered are : Physical Structure Strength Tensile behavior Absorbability Biological behavior Suture Materials may be absorbable or Non-absorbable : Non-Absorbable Suture Materials : Silk Linen Surgical Steel Nylon Polyester Polypropylene Absorbable Suture Materials : Catgut (Absorption by phagocytosis and enzymatic degradation) Plain ( 7-10 days ) Chromic (21-28 days) Polyglactin (absorption by hydrolysis) - (60-90 days) Polydiaxone (absorption by hydrolysis) - (90 - 120 days) Polyglycapone (180 days)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. In the closure of the abdominal wall, the mass closure technique is the usual method. In this large bites are taken in short steps using nylon or polypropylene (non-absorbable) or polydioxanone (PDS, slowly absorbable) sutures. The length of suture material used should be at least four times the length of the incision to be closed; this is to minimize the risk of wound dehiscence or incisional hernia. Option B. Knot tying, one of the most basic of surgical techniques, should be thoroughly mastered as sutures lose 50% of their strength at the knot. Option D. Suture materials are generally classified as synthetic (non-absorbable) and natural (absorbable). Synthetic suture materials produce minimal tissue reaction. Sutures from biological or natural material elicit tissue reactions and hence are unpredictable in their behavior.

Extraedge:

When using absorbable material , always be mindful that c ertain tissues require wound support for longer than others ; for example, muscular aponeuroses compared with subcutaneous tissues Biliary anastomoses require an absorbable material that will not promote tissue reaction or stone formation. Bowel anastomosis is usually performed using polyglactin, PDS, or polypropylene based on the surgeon’s preference

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

options.label: A
options.text: The currently favored technique of bowel anastomosis is the one-layer extramucosal interrupted method

options.label: B
options.text: The bowel must be prepared prior to any anastomosis

options.label: C
options.text: It is essential that in end-to-end anastomosis the bowel ends should match the diameter

options.label: D
options.text: In vascular anastomosis, polypropylene is the suture material to be used

questions.correct_answer: B. The bowel must be prepared prior to any anastomosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The bowel must be prepared prior to any anastomosis Bowel preparation prior to anastomosis is a principle of the past. Conventional bowel preparation provides little benefit and may be harmful. However, meticulous prevention of spillage of bowel contents must be followed.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A: The currently favored technique of bowel anastomosis is one-layer extramucosal closure because it causes the least tissue necrosis and luminal narrowing. The suture must include the submucosa, which, by virtue of its high collagen content, is the most stable suture layer. Several studies have shown that there are very little differences between the single-layer and two-layer anastomosis as long as the basic surgical principles are followed, which include ensuring a good blood supply, tension-free anastomosis and use of atraumatic bowel clamps to minimize contamination. Option C: In end-to-end anastomosis, the bowel ends must be of similar diameter. Following resection for intestinal obstruction when the bowel ends to be anastomosed are unequal, a side-to-side or end-to-side anastomosis is done. In case the discrepancy is minimal, end-to-end anastomosis can be carried out by making a cut into the antimesenteric border (Cheatle split) of the distal collapsed lumen to bring the diameter into line with that of the proximal bowel. Option D: In vascular anastomosis when prosthetic material or graft is used, the anastomosis will never be integrated into the graft tissues. Therefore, the suture line needs to be permanent. Hence, polypropylene, as it is not biodegradable, is the ideal suture to be used.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

options.label: A
options.text: A drain is best inserted through the end of a wound so as not to have another scar

options.label: B
options.text: ‘When in doubt drain’ dictum is no longer valid

options.label: C
options.text: Drains are mandatory after a thoracotomy

options.label: D
options.text: Drains are usually used following exploration of the common bile duct

questions.correct_answer: A. A drain is best inserted through the end of a wound so as not to have another scar
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A drain is best inserted through the end of a wound so as not to have another scar Drains are best placed through a separate incision. They should not be brought out through the end of an incision, because this leads to an increased chance of wound infection.

Highyeild:

Drains: Drains are inserted to allow fluid that might collect in a body cavity to drain freely to the surface. The fluid to be drained may include blood, serum, pus, urine, feces, bile, lymph, or air Classification : Open Drain(Passive drainage) Closed Drains Suctioned Drains(Active Drainage) Non-Suction Drains (Passive Drainage) Role Of Drains in Modern Surgery Help remove the collection of purulent material, blood, serous fluid, bile, chyle, pancreatic or intestinal secretions; Act as a signal for postoperative hemorrhage or anastomotic leakages Provide a track for long-term drainage

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B: The use of drains depends upon a surgeon’s individual preference and type of surgery. Again, after the same operation, one surgeon might drain whilst another might not. Protagonists believe that drains remove collections within a wound or peritoneal cavity and might indicate postoperative hemorrhage; those not in favor of drains claim that they increase the incidence of wound infections, abdominal pain, and hospital stays and that they reduce pulmonary function. Option C: Following a thoracotomy, drains are always inserted to remove air and blood; they are connected to an underwater seal to which sometimes a suction pressure of 10 to 20 mm Hg is applied. When removing a chest drain, the patient is always asked to take a deep breath and hold it (Valsalva maneuver) to prevent air from being sucked into the pleural cavity during the removal of the tube. Option D: After exploration of the common bile duct most surgeons insert a T-tube to remain in place for 10 days . This is to allow free postoperative bile drainage whilst there is spasm at the sphincter of Oddi ; additionally, when a postoperative T-tube cholangiogram is done after 10 days, it helps to show up any residual stones that might have been left inadvertently. T-tubes are left for 10 days to prevent intraperitoneal bile leakage after removal.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

options.label: A
options.text: The two types of diathermy in use are monopolar and bipolar

options.label: B
options.text: Monopolar diathermy is ideal for microsurgery and delicate procedures

options.label: C
options.text: Bipolar diathermy is ideal for patients who have pacemakers

options.label: D
options.text: Accidental burns are more common when monopolar diathermy is used

questions.correct_answer: B. Monopolar diathermy is ideal for microsurgery and delicate procedures
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Monopolar diathermy is ideal for microsurgery and delicate procedures Monopolar diathermy is never to be used for microsurgery and delicate procedures. Bipolar diathermy should be the choice.

Highyeild:

ELECTROSURGERY Employs high-frequency electrical current to assist in making surgical incisions, dissection of tissue, and achieving hemostasis Principle Of Electrosurgery: Alternating current (AC), a type of current wherein current periodically changes direction, is solely employed in electrosurgery. Types In Monopolar surgery , the electrical current created in the ESU passes through a single electrode (diathermy pencil) to the tissue, causing the desired tissue effect (cut or coagulation). Electrical energy is passed via the diathermy probe and returned to the machine via the patient earth plate. Earth plate must be far away from pacemaker. It must not be used in circumcision and surgeries near the nerve. In Bipolar diathermy , the two active electrodes are usually represented by the limbs of a pair of diathermy forceps, blades of scissors, or graspers. It needs no Earth Plate. The current is between the limbs of the diathermy probe. Can be safely used in pacemakers. Safe in surgeries near nerve and Circumcision . Effects of Diathermy : Coagulation: to achieve hemostasis; Cutting: incision and dissection of tissues during surgery Hazards of Diathermy : Accidental Burns (More with Monopolar Diathermy) Electrocution Explosion Channelling Interference with implantable electronic devices Occupational hazards from surgical smoke Laparoscopic surgery and diathermy injuries

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A: There are two types of diathermy, monopolar and bipolar. The principle is used to coagulate, cut and fulgurate. The most common type is monopolar diathermy where normal electric current is converted into high-frequency alternating current (HFAC). In this, HFAC is passed through the patient’s body tissues and returned to the machine by a large surface plate (70 cm2) called the indifferent electrode. The surface area of contact of the active electrode is small compared with the indifferent electrode; this concentrated powerful current produces heat at the operation site, thus exercising the desired effect. Option C: In bipolar diathermy , the HFAC passes from the diathermy machine down one prong of the forceps through to the tissue being held and returned to the machine via the second prong thus concentrating the desired effect on the small piece of tissue held by the forceps. Therefore , bipolar diathermy is ideal for patients who have a pacemaker because the current does not flow through other tissues of the body. Option D: Accidental burns are more common in monopolar diathermy for the following reasons : the indifferent electrode may be incorrectly applied with inadequate contact, the patient being earthed by metal contact on the operating table, there may be faulty insulation of the diathermy leads and accidental contact of the active electrode may occur with other metal instruments in use.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is wrong with regards to the knotting technique?

options.label: A
options.text: The knot must be tied firmly

options.label: B
options.text: The knot must be as small as possible

options.label: C
options.text: The suture material must be laid rectangle during tying

options.label: D
options.text: The thread should only be grasped at the free end

questions.correct_answer: C. The suture material must be laid rectangle during tying
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The suture material must be laid rectangle during tying Knotting Techniques : Knot tying is one of the most fundamental techniques in surgery and a poorly constructed knot may jeopardize an otherwise successful surgical procedure General Principles : The knot must be tied firmly, but without strangulating the tissues. The knot must be as small as possible to minimize the amount of foreign material. The knot must be tightened without exerting any tension or pressure on the tissues being ligated , i.e. the knot should be bedded down carefully, only exerting pressure against counter-pressure from the index finger or thumb. The suture material must not be ‘sawed’ as this weakens the thread and cuts through delicate tissue like a cheese wire. The suture material must be laid square during tying ; otherwise, tension during tightening may cause breakage or fracture of the thread. When tying an instrument knot, the thread should only be grasped at the free end , as gripping the thread with the needle holder can damage the material, resulting in breakage or fracture. The standard surgical knot is the reef knot with a third throw for security , although with monofilament sutures six throws are required for security. When added security is required, a surgeon’s knot using a two-throw technique is advisable to prevent slippage . When using a continuous suture technique, an Aberdeen knot may be used for the final knot. When the suture is cut after knotting, the ends should be left about 1–2 mm long to prevent unraveling . This is particularly important when using monofilament material

questions.text: With respect to the management of the open abdomen, choose the correctly matched option: Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-b , 2-a , 3-d , 4-c

Highyeild:

Abdominal Closure : Minimization of tissue damage is imperative, and this may be done by limiting the incorporation of the abdominal wall musculature in the closure Temporary Abdominal Closure (TAC) : Goal: To minimize damage to the abdominal contents and minimize adherence of abdominal contents to the anterior abdominal wall while retaining the ability to close the fascia primarily at a subsequent operation Indications : Damage control Severe hemorrhage Hypothermia, acidosis, coagulopathy Delayed definitive operation secondary to patient’s physiologic state Intra-abdominal hypertension or compartment syndrome Major abdominal and/or retroperitoneal tissue edema Questionable visceral viability Planned acute reoperation Severe intra-abdominal sepsis Triage Management of the Open Abdomen : After hemorrhage and/or contamination control, intraoperatively, the primary goal in the initial resuscitation of the patient with an open abdomen is the correction of hypothermia, coagulopathy, and acidosis . Timing of initial reexploration can usually be achieved within 24 to 72 hours. Fluids should be restricted with attempts at diuresis if indicated, and infections strictly controlled. Definitive closure should only be attempted when the underlying condition is resolving During the Stage 3 or 4, it is important to assess the ability to close the fascia without undue tension due to tissue edema or loss of domain. This can be assessed by measuring intra-abdominal pressure and/or changes in peak inspiratory pressure during the closure Early enteral nutrition in the patient with an open abdomen should be strongly considered in all patients with a viable gastrointestinal tract

questions.text: Which of the following device/technique is unsafe in patients with an implanted electronic device?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Monopolar Devices

Highyeild:

Monopolar Electrosurgery Performed using a current generator, a handheld electrode that delivers current to the patient, and a second large electrode (the “pad”) that returns current to complete the circuit. With a continuous waveform (“cut” mode), the monopolar device cuts through tissue with little thermal spread and minimal coagulation. With an intermittent waveform (“coagulation” mode), current is delivered over less than 10% of the time that the device is activated and is interspersed with short periods of inactivity Advantages: Multiple Modes(Cut mode,Coagulation Mode & Blend Mode) Disadvantages: Unsafe with the Implanted electronic device

questions.text: In which of the following conditions, monopolar diathermy is preferred?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above In Monopolar surgery , the electrical current created in the ESU passes through a single electrode (diathermy pencil) to the tissue, causing the desired tissue effect (cut or coagulation). Electrical energy is passed via the diathermy probe and returned to the machine via the patient earth plate. The Earth plate must be far away from the pacemaker. It must not be used in circumcision and surgeries near the nerve. In Bipolar diathermy , the two active electrodes are usually represented by the limbs of a pair of diathermy forceps, blades of scissors, or graspers. It needs no Earth Plate. The current is between the limbs of the diathermy probe. Can be safely used in pacemakers. Safe in surgeries near nerves and Circumcision . Effects of Diathermy : Coagulation: to achieve hemostasis; Cutting: incision and dissection of tissues during surgery Hazards of Diathermy : Burns Electrocution Explosion Channeling Interference with implantable electronic devices Occupational hazards from surgical smoke
